metadata.title: Synthesis and characterization of new ferrocenylamine sulfide ligands and their palladium complexes as catalysts for selective hydrogenation

of Molecular Catalysis, 75 (1992) 221-233 221 M3032 Synthesis and characterization of new ferrocenylamine sulfide ligands and their palladium complexes as catalysts for selective hydrogenation Chun-Hsiung Wang and Carl H. Brubaker, Jr.* Department of Chemistry, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824 (USA) (Received May 20, 1991; revised April 28, 1992) Abstract A series of new achiral and chiral ferrocenylamine sulfides and their palladium complexes of type (CSH6)Fe[(C5H3)(CHZNRZ)(SR')]PdCl2 (R=Et; R'= Me, Et, 4-chlorophenyl, p-tolyl; R=n-Pr, R'= Me, Et), (S,R)-(CrH5)Fe[(C,H3)(CHMeNR2)(SR')]PdClz (R=Et, n-Pr; R' =Me) and (R,S)-(C5H5)Fe[(C,H3)(CHMeNR2)(SR')]PdCl2 (R=Et, n-Pr; R'=Et, i-Pr) were synthesized. Their applications as homogeneous catalysts in hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclooctadiene have been examined. These new catalysts showed superior activity and selectivity over other palladium ferrocenylamine sulfide complexes. Their catalytic activities were dependent on the steric bulkiness of both the amine and sulfide substituents. The effects of pressure on the reaction rates and selectivities were also investigated. Introduction The preparation, characterization and catalytic applications of ferrocenyl sulfide complexes of palladium and platinum have previously been reported by this laboratory [ 1-5 ]. In this work we report the preparation of new ferrocenyl complexes such as (C5H5)Fe[(C5H3)(CHZNRz)(SR')]PdCI2 where R=Et, n-Pr; R'=Me, Et, (R,S)-(C5H5)Fe[(C6H3)(CHMeNR2)(SR')]PdCl2, R=Et, n-Pr; R' =Et, i-Pr, (S,R)-(CrH5)Fe[(CrH3)(CHMeNRz)(SR')]PdC12, R=Et, n-Pr; R'=Me and (C5H5)Fe[(C5H3)(CHZSEt)(SMe)]PdC]2. The ligands were prepared by converting ferrocenylamine sulfides into ferrocenyl ethylacetates then treating them with appropriate dialkylamines [6] (Scheme 1). These ligands then chelate with palladium dichloride to produce the desired complexes. The air-stable palladium complexes are selective catalysts for the reduction of coiAjugated dienes to monoenes. Experimental Air-sensitive reagents were manipulated in a prepurified argon or nitrogen atmosphere by using standard Schlenk-ware techniques. All solvents used *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 222 R H R H R H C\ " Me C C N. OAc N, AC20 i e R, HN~ Fe . i e R' R R"= H R"= H R"= H R=Et R'= Me, Et (1,2) R'= Me (3) R'= Me,Et, ' ` CI, &CH3 (4-7) R"= CH3 R= rrPr R'= Me ((SR)13) R'= Me, Et (8,9) R'= Et, rPr ((RS)14,15) HCI R= fPr, rgu R'= Et (10,11) CI R"= CH3 R= Et,/fPr Fe S R'= Me ((SR)16,17) Me R'= Et ((R,S)18.19) R'=tar ((RS)20,21) NaSEt ~O%^SEt Fe~S Me (12) Scheme 1. were reagent grade and were distilled by standard methods [7]. Dimethylaminomethylferrocene, dialkyl disulfides and dialkylamines were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received. 1-Dimethylaminomethyl-2alkylthioferrocene (1, 2), (R,S)-1-(1-dimethyla.minoethyl)-2-alkylthioferrocene ((R,S)14, (R,S)15) and (S,R)-1-(1-dimethylaminoethyl)-2-alkylthioferrocene ((S,R)13) were prepared according to the reported procedure [8]. 'H and 13C NMR spectra in either chloroform-dl or acetone-ds were obtained by use of a Varian Gemini-300 spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded by means of a Nicolet 740 FT-IR spectrometer by using neat films between KBr plates for liquid samples and CsI pellets for solid samples. Mass spectra were obtained by use of a Finnigan 4000 instrument with an Incos data system at 70 eV. Melting points were determined by a Thomas-Hoover capillary apparatus and are uncorrected. Gas chromatography was carried out by using a Hewlet-Packard 5880A instrument with a 25m GB-1 capillary column. Elemental analyses were performed by Galbraith Laboratories Inc., Knoxville, TN. 223 General procedure for preparation of ligands AchiraL Ligands The ligands of the type (C,H5)Fe(C5H3)(CHZNRz)(SR') where R=Et, R'= Me, Et, 4-chlorophenyl, p-tolyl; R = n-Pr, R'= Me, Et; R = i-Pr, i-Bu, R'= Et were prepared as follows: A 64 ml portion of acetic anhydride was added to a 6.0 g sample of 1-dimethylamino-2-methylthioferrocene 1 and heated at 100 C for 2 h. After the reaction was completed, excess acetic anhydride was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was chromatographed on an alumina gel column with hexane 10 =hexane/dichloromethane as eluent. The yield was almost quantitative. A solution of 1 g (3.3 mmol) methylthioferrocenyl ethyl acetate 3 and 3.1 ml diethylamine in 30 ml methanol was refluxed for 7 h. The solvent was removed, and ether was added. The solution was washed with brine, dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, and evaporated. The residue was purified by column chromatography (silica, 10:1 hexane/ether) to give 0.67 g (64% yield) of 1-diethylaminoethyl-2-methylthioferrocene 4. Preparation of chiral ligands Chiral ferrocenylamine sulfide ligands ((S,R)16-(R, S)21) were synthesized by a similar procedure except the chiral alkylthioferrocenyl ethyl acetates were chromatographed on silica gel instead of alumina. Solutions of the ferrocenyl acetates with appropriate amines were stirred at room temperature for 24-48 h without heating. Synthesis of ferrocenyl suO Ligands To 1 g (3.3 mmol) of 3 was added, via syringe, 20 ml 1.0 M HCl in diethyl ether at 0 C [ 91. The solution was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for a further 3 h. The solvent was evacuated and a fresh 20 ml portion of dried ether was added to the residue. To this solution was added, via syringe, a mixture of 2.5 ml ethanethiol and 80 mg Na in 20 ml ether at 0 C. After stirring for 3 h, 10 ml of saturated aqueous NaHC03 was added. The resulting organic layer and ether extracts from the aqueous layer were combined, washed, dried and evaporated. The product was purified by column chromatography to give 0.85 g (84% overall yield) 1-methylthio-2ethylthiomethylferrocene 12. Preparation of palladium complexes Complexes 22-(R,S)34 were prepared from benzene solutions of 0.2 g (PhCN)ZPdC12 and a slight excess of ligand in an approximately 1:1.1 molar ratio. The mixture was stirred overnight and the resulting precipitates were collected by filtration, washed with cold benzene and ether. Pure crystals were obtained by recrystallization from dichloromethane/hexane (Scheme 2). The recrystallization was performed by dissolving palladium complexes in a minimum amount of dichloromethane, then adding hexane until the solution turned cloudy. 224 Rk H R H C~ , R 1,C~ , R Q NCR Q NCR (PhCN)2PdC12 R, R,\ CI 4~> 4~> CI R"= H R=Et R'= Me, Et, &CI, &CH3 (22-25) R= n-P r R'= Me, Et (26,27) R"= CH3 R= Et, r;-Pr R'= Me ((S,R)29,30) R'= Et ((RS)31,32) R'= i-Pr ((RS)33,34) .S/C2Hs ~SiC2Hs I S (PhCN)2PdCl2 I Fe I CH S---Pd-CI CHI C!Z~b C~ CI (28) Scheme 2. Hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclooctOiO The palladium catalysts (1.0 x 10-5 mol), 4.5 ml acetone and 3.725 x 10-3 mol substrate were added to a 100-n-1 pressure bottle equipped with a pressure gauge and a stirring bar. The bottle was flushed with HZ several times, then fixed at 62 psi. The uptake of hydrogen was monitored by the pressure drop. The product was distilled from the catalyst and analyzed using 1H NMR and GC. The 1,3-cyclooctadiene:cyclooctene ratio was determined by integration of the 1H NMR spectral peaks in the olefin region. The (1,3cyclooctadiene+cyclooctene):cyclooctane ratio was determined by GC. Results and discussion Dimethylaminoferrocenyl sulfides (1, 2) were first converted to sulfidoferrocenyl ethyl acetate, then treated with diethylamine or di-n-propylamine to give diethylaminoferrocenyl sulfides (4-7) and di-n-propylaminoferrocenyl 225 sulfides (8, 9) respectively [6]. The chiral ferrocenylamine sulfide ligands ((S,R)16-(R,S)21) were also prepared in this way with some modification. Their palladium complexes were prepared according to the reported procedure [8]. We also report the first synthesis of sulfidoferrocenyl palladium complex 1-ethylthio-2-methylthioferrocene palladium chloride, 28, containing two thioether functional groups on the same cyclopentadiene ring. The ferrocenyl sulfide ligand can be prepared by treating the corresponding ferrocenyl ethyl acetate with ethanethiol, but the yield is low (ca. 10-20g'o). An alternative route was adopted and ligand 12 was generated in situ by first converting methylthioferrocenyl ethyl acetate into halide, then stirring with NaSEt [91. The yield was improved to 84%. The ligands were then treated with (PhCN)2PdC12 to give complex 28. Ferrocenylamino sulfide ligands of the type (C,H5)Fe(C5H3)(SEt)(CHZN-i-Pr2) (10) and (C5HS)Fe(C5H3)(SEt)(CH2Ni-But) (11) were also synthesized [6]. However, we were unable to obtain their palladium complexes, probably due to the steric hindrance of the bulky isopropyl- and isobutylamine groups. The 1H NMR data. for the new ligands and complexes are presented in Tables 1 through 4, while the 13C NMR, IR and elemental analyses data are available as Supplementary Material from the authors. Homogeneous hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclooctadiene Homogeneous and heterogeneous hydrogenations of a diene to a monoene by using ferrocenylamine sulfide or selenide complexes have been previously reported [ 1-5, 10 ]. It was found that both palladium and platinum ferrocenylamine selenide complexes fail to effectively catalyze homogeneous hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclooctadiene [10]. A possible explanation for this lack of catalytic activity resides in the metal-sulfur and metal-selenium bond strength. Cleavage of the metal-sulfur bond is important to selective hydrogenation [3] and since the metal-selenium bond is stronger than the metal-sulfur bond, the palladium and platinum ferrocenylaxnine selenide complexes exhibit no catalytic activity. The hydrogenation was carried out in the presence of acetone; no hydrogen uptake was observed if CHZC12, CC14 or THF was used [10]. Dissociation of a metal-sulfur bond by acetone to form a catalyst-acetone intermediate, followed by Hz uptake, may account for this observation [3, 11 ]. Recently in this laboratory, we were able to improve the selectivity to close to 100% by modifying the sulfido substituent(s) on either one or both of the two cyclopentadiene rings at the ferrocenyl ligands [4, 5]. Nevertheless, the effect of replacing the 1-dimethylamino group in the catalyst by other more bulky alkylamino groups had never been investigated. It was therefore decided to study these influences upon the hydrogenation reactions. The catalytic activity of the new palladium catalysts (22-(R,S)34) on the hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclooctadiene was examined and the results are presented in Tables 5-7. In general, the hydrogenation was very efficient without an induction period, except for catalyst 22, which had an induction time of 2 h. The dependence of the hydrogenation on the catalysts is shown in Tables 5 and 6. Increasing the steric bulkiness on both the amine and sulfide group increased the reaction rate with retention of the yield and selectivity. In either the achiral or chiral catalytic system, the catalysts with a methylthio ligand (22, 28, (S,R)29, (S,R)30) performed at a slower rate than those with other sulfide substituents; the catalysts with the more bulky n-propylamine substituents also reacted more rapidly than those with the ethylamine group. This observation was even more evident with the achiral catalytic system. Possibly the bulky sulfide and/or amine group pushes the substrate away from the metal center during the hydrogenation stage and thus loosens the Pd-substrate binding [ 12, 131. This explanation was further supported because the activities of the chiral catalysts were higher than those of the achiral ones (compare Tables 5 and 6, in which the additional steric effects exerted by the methyl groups on the chiral catalysts are seen to increase reaction rate significantly). As for catalyst 28, which bears two sulfide groups, the reaction was much slower than for the other catalysts with one sulfide and one amine group. A possible explanation is again that the ethylthio group is not as bulky as the amine group, thus the Pd-substrate bonding is stronger in catalyst 28 and the reaction rate is reduced. Attempts to investigate the influence on the catalytic activity by replacing the 1-dimethylamine substituent by the even more bulky di-i-propylamine or di-i-butylamine failed, due to the inaccessibility of the palladium in the complexes. The effect of initial reaction pressure on the reaction time, yield and selectivity is shown on Table 7. The conversions were all 100% and the selectivity decreased slightly as the pressure rose. This catalytic system has the best performance at 62 psi (entry 2), however, hydrogenation can still be carried out efficiently at pressures as low as 20 psi (ca. 1.36 atm). In order to evaluate the activity of complexes reported here, catalysts 27 and (R,S)32 are compared with previously known Pd complexes (Table 8). Compare entries 4, 5, 6 (complexes with one dimethylamine substituent and with sulfide substituent(s) at either one or both Cp rings) with the first two entries; the hydrogenation activity is about three orders of magnitude faster than that of the chelating bis(phosphine) (entry 1) [141 and about the same order of magnitude as the amine catalyst in entry 2 [ 151. If one compares the activity of (R,S)32 with the chelating bis(phosphine) catalyst in entry 1, catalyst (R,S)32 is about five orders of magnitude faster. Those modified with sulfido substituents show about the same activities (entries 4, 5, 6), while entries 7, 8 show the difference resulting from replacing dimethylamine group by di-n-propylamine group. On comparing entries 7, 8 with entries 4, 5, 6, the achiral catalyst 27 is seen to be 5 to 20 times as active as entries 4, 5; while the chiral catalyst (R,S)32 was even more rapid (28-117 times). Thus, we were able to improve the activity of the ferrocenyl sulfide complexes by a factor of up to two by modification of the amine substituents instead of the sulfides. 233 In this hydrogenation, we have found that besides the sulfido group, the alkylamino group in the catalysts also effectively influenced the reaction rate. These new catalysts performed at high rate (up to 1.1 x 10' mol/mol Pd per h) with retention of conversion and selectivity. A further investigation of the catalytic activities of these catalysts in the reduction of carbon-carbon bonded conjugated dienes and a, /3-unsaturated carboxylic acids is in progress. Supplementary material available Tables of "C NMR, IR and analytical data for the new ligands (4-12, (S,R)16-(R, S)21) and palladium catalysts (22-(R, S)34) (8 pages) are available, and can be obtained from the authors. X244 92801273 0304-5102(92)80127-3 10.1016/0304-5102(92)80127-3 Synthesis and characterization of new ferrocenylamine sulfide ligands and their palladium complexes as catalysts for selective hydrogenation Chun-Hsiung Wang Carl H. Brubaker Jr. ∗ Department of Chemistry, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824 USA * Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. A series of new achiral and chiral ferrocenylamine sulfides and their palladium complexes of type (C5H5)Fe[(C5H3)(CH2NR2)(SR′)]PdCl2 (R=Et; R′=Me, Et, 4-chlorophenyl, p-tolyl; R=n-Pr, R′=Me, Et), (S,R)-(C5H5)Fe[(C5H3)(CHMeNR2)(SR′)]PdCl2 (R=Et, n-Pr; R′=Me) and (R,S)-(C5H5)Fe[(C5H3)(CHMeNR2)(SR ) ́ ]PdCl2 (R=Et, n-Pr; R′=Et, i-Pr) were synthesized. Their applications as homogeneous catalysts in hydrogenation of 1,3-cyclo-octadiene have been examined. These new catalysts showed superior activity and selectivity over other palladium ferrocenylamine sulfide complexes. Their catalytic activities were dependent on the steric bulkiness of both the amine and sulfide substituents. The effects of pressure on the reaction rates and selectivities were also investigated.
